caption.center: THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, Respondent, v. FRED CHARLEMAGNE,

court.center: Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, First Department.

opinion.posture: Judgment, Supreme Court, New York County (Joan C. Sudolnik, J.), rendered June 15, 2001, convicting defendant, after a jury trial, of burglary in the second degree and possession of burglar's tools, and sentencing him, as a persistent violent felony offender, to concurrent terms of 17 years to life and 1 year, respectively, unanimously affirmed.

Ind. 7395/00 Robert S. Dean, Center for Appellate Litigation, New York (Lisa Joy Robertson of counsel), for appellant.
Fred Charlemagne, appellant pro se.
Robert M. Morgenthau, District Attorney, New York (Melissa A. Rubin of counsel), for respondent.
opinion.panel: Before: Nardelli, J.P., Tom, Ellerin, Williams, JJ.
opinion.opinion_text:
Since defendant did not request any further relief after his objections were sustained, his challenge to the prosecutor's summation remark concerning defendant's right to a trial is unpreserved (People v.Medina, 53 N.Y.2d 951), and we decline to review it in the interest of justice. Were we to review this claim, we would find that although the prosecutor's remarks could be viewed as improperly denigrating defendant's exercise of his right to proceed to trial (see People v. Rivera,116 A.D.2d 371,Page 397 373-374), we find any error to be harmless in light of the court's curative actions and its final instructions to the jury, along with the overwhelming evidence of defendant's guilt.
We have considered and rejected the claims contained in defendant's pro se supplemental brief.
THIS CONSTITUTES THE DECISION AND ORDER OF THE SUPREME COURT, APPELLATE DIVISION, FIRST DEPARTMENT.
